questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician for a 4-month history of worsening neck pain that now radiates to his arms. He is a retired bouldering professional and has recently also noticed difficulty reaching holds above his head. He has a 10-year history of chronic neck pain treated with topical diclofenac and ibuprofen as needed. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness to palpation over the neck and subscapular region. There is limited neck motion due to pain. Muscle strength is 3/5 for shoulder abduction and elbow flexion bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased in both forearms and bilateral thumbs and index fingers. Biceps reflex is 1+ bilaterally and patellar reflex is 3+ in the left leg and 3+ in the right leg. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Atherosclerotic occlusion of the anterior spinal artery
Mutation of the superoxide dismutase gene
Cavitation of the cervical spinal cord

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has cervical spondylotic myelopathy (CSM), which is caused by the narrowing of the spinal canal due to degenerative changes of the spine. This condition most commonly affects older adults (> 50 years of age) and usually manifests with neck pain (which can radiate to the arms due to concomitant nerve root compression), paresthesias, sensory deficits (e.g., impaired light touch sensation and dull discrimination/pain sensation), findings of lower motor neuron injury at the level of the lesion (e.g., hyporeflexia), and findings of upper motor neuron injury below the level of the lesion (e.g., hyperreflexia, Babinski sign). Diminished biceps reflex in this patient suggests a lesion at the level of C5-C6, the most commonly affected region. Other manifestations of CSM include gait instability and, less frequently, bladder dysfunction. The diagnosis is confirmed by MRI.

B) INCORRECT:

Atherosclerotic occlusion of the anterior spinal artery (ASA) causes ASA syndrome (ASAS), which can manifest with muscle weakness and findings of upper motor neuron (UMN) injury (e.g., hyperreflexia, Babinski sign). ASAS can also manifest with signs of lower motor neuron (LMN) injury (e.g., decreased muscle tone, hyporeflexia) in the acute stages. However, patients with ASAS do not present with findings of LMN and UMN injury at different levels at the same time. Moreover, the ASA supplies the anterior ⅔ of the spinal cord, so its occlusion typically causes loss of temperature and pain sensation (due to ischemia of the spinothalamic tracts) but no loss of light touch sensation, for which the dorsal columns (supplied by the posterior spinal arteries) are responsible. Finally, since the artery of Adamkiewicz is the most commonly occluded artery, the arms are not typically involved in ASAS; affected individuals usually present only with involvement of the lower extremities.
Image Description:

Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune destruction of acetylcholine receptors is the underlying cause of myasthenia gravis (MG), which can manifest with muscle weakness and most commonly affects male individuals between 60 and 80 years of age. However, the majority of patients with MG present with ocular symptoms of ptosis and diplopia; limb weakness alone is an uncommon manifestation of MG. Moreover, MG would not explain the history of worsening neck pain, changes in deep tendon reflexes, and sensory deficits seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A superoxide dismutase gene (SOD1) mutation is associated with a genetic predisposition to amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Patients with ALS present with findings of both lower motor neuron injury (i.e., hyporeflexia) and upper motor neuron injury (i.e., hyperreflexia, Babinski sign). ALS also typically manifests around 50–70 years of age. However, manifestations of ALS are usually asymmetric, whereas this patient has symmetric findings. Moreover, sensory loss and neck pain are not common in ALS.

E) INCORRECT:

Cavitation of the cervical spinal cord occurs in syringomyelia, which can manifest with radiating neck pain, decreased muscle strength, and hyporeflexia in a “cape-like” distribution (i.e., neck, shoulders, upper limbs). Moreover, an expanded syrinx can cause hyperreflexia in the lower extremities. However, affected individuals classically have dissociated sensory impairment with loss of pain and temperature sensation (due to damage to the crossing spinothalamic tracts) and intact light touch sensation (unaffected dorsal columns). This patient's history of chronic neck pain and decreased light touch sensation make a different underlying cause much more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

A postinfectious demyelinating reaction can cause Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), which can manifest with symmetric paresthesias and muscle weakness in the upper extremities. However, patients with GBS typically present with an ascending flaccid paralysis in a “stocking-glove” distribution, which is not seen here. Moreover, findings of upper motor neuron injury (e.g., hyperreflexia, Babinski sign) in the lower extremities are not expected in GBS.
questions.hint: This condition most commonly occurs in patients with degenerative spinal changes.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman with a history of asthma and chronic neck pain radiating to the right arm reports increased difficulty walking for the past 6 months. She can walk only one block before having to rest because of weakness and stiffness in both legs. She has had several falls after tripping, an increase in frequency of urination, and frequent constipation. She also reports some difficulties using her hands to open jars or button her shirt.
Physical examination reveals mild weakness and increased tone in both legs, hyperreflexia in all extremities, decreased sensation throughout the legs, and a slow, spastic gait. No atrophy or fasciculations are observed.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis typically causes upper and lower motor-neuron findings, such as atrophy and fasciculations but does not cause sensory loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Spinocerebellar ataxia is a rare condition typically associated with a wide-based, ataxic gait rather than a spastic gait; it does not cause neck pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervical facet-joint arthritis can be associated with joint hypertrophy, which could cause a compressive radiculopathy and lower motor-neuron findings in the arms. However, the myelopathic symptoms and signs in this case (weakness and hyperreflexia in the legs and bowel and bladder symptoms) are due to compression of the spinal cord, which would be a very rare finding in cervical facet-joint arthritis with hypertrophy.

D) CORRECT:

Cervical spondylotic myelopathy is a condition in which degeneration of the intervertebral discs and surrounding structures leads to stenosis of the spinal canal and damage to the cervical spinal cord. It generally occurs in older adults and is subacute in onset. Typical presenting symptoms include neck pain, gait spasticity, sphincter dysfunction, and sensory loss. Cervical radiculopathy may also be present.

Physical examination typically reveals upper motor-neuron findings such as hyperreflexia, increased muscle tone, and weakness. MRI of the cervical spine can confirm the clinical diagnosis and help exclude other potential causes of cervical cord compression, such as a tumor.

Key learning point: The combination of slowly progressive neck pain, weakness and hyperreflexia in the legs, gait spasticity, urinary frequency, constipation, and sensory loss is most likely to be caused by cervical spondylotic myelopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Polymyositis causes proximal muscle weakness but would not cause sensory loss or upper motor-neuron findings such as spasticity.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man with no known medical history developed neck pain and tingling down both of his arms 10 days ago after returning home from the gym. The neck pain has improved slightly with ibuprofen, but the tingling persists. He notes that two mornings ago, his legs felt heavy while he was getting out of the car. He has been afraid to exercise but has not noticed any changes in his gait or in the use of his hands. He reports no bowel or bladder symptoms.
His mental status and cranial nerves are intact. On motor examination, he has intact strength in all four extremities, except for 4/5 strength on right elbow flexion (biceps) and 4+/5 strength on left elbow flexion. Reflexes are present in the upper and lower extremities but diminished at the right biceps. The big toes on both feet point upward when the soles are stimulated (positive Babinski sign), and there is mild spasticity in the lower extremities. The patient has intact sensation throughout all four extremities despite the tingling that extends down both of his arms. There is no spinal sensory level. He has a normal gait but says his legs feel weaker than they used to be.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has bilateral upper-extremity paresthesia and biceps weakness, indicating a likely C6 radiculopathy. The accompanying increased tone and heaviness in the lower extremities, along with upward-pointing toes, raises concern for coexisting myelopathy (compression of the spinal cord).

In older adults, cervical spine pathology often stems from degenerative disease and stenosis, but in younger patients (such as this one), disk herniation tends to be more common, most frequently at the C5–C6 level. Herniation can be precipitated by trauma but is often spontaneous.

Disk protrusion can result in a radiculopathy, but it may also cause myelopathy when there is spinal-cord compression and resulting long-tract signs (such as this patient's subjective leg heaviness and positive Babinski sign bilaterally). Bowel and bladder complaints, along with abnormal lower-extremity sensation and obvious weakness, may also be evident in patients with myelopathy.

A cervical spine MRI is noninvasive and allows for the best visualization of cervical stenosis and of disk protrusion resulting in radiculopathy and myelopathy. In addition, MRI can provide more detail of intramedullary spinal cord pathology (e.g., spinal cord signal abnormality related to compression). Although contrast administration is not required to appreciate a compressive radiculopathy or myelopathy, it should be considered, particularly if there is high concern for inflammatory or infectious etiologies of intramedullary myelopathy/myelitis (e.g., transverse myelitis).

To prevent permanent motor deficits, patients with cervical myelopathy should be referred for surgical intervention when symptoms are progressive or severe; urgent referral is necessary if there are bowel or bladder complaints or spastic limb weakness. Sensory and pain components are often treated conservatively with neck immobilization (cervical collar), nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, cyclobenzaprine, glucocorticoids, and physical therapy.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a patient with evidence of cervical myelopathy on physical examination is immediate cervical spine imaging and likely surgical intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has evidence of spinal cord involvement, manifesting in quantifiable biceps-muscle weakness that is progressing to involve the lower extremities. He therefore requires neuroimaging and probable surgical intervention rather than conservative management with cyclobenzaprine.

C) INCORRECT:

Although a CT myelogram can show disk protrusion and canal stenosis, it is somewhat invasive and does not adequately visualize injury to the spinal cord (as MRI does with a cord signal change).

D) INCORRECT:

Nerve-conduction studies and electromyography can help to localize affected nerve roots but are not absolutely necessary and could delay more-urgent cervical imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has evidence of spinal cord involvement, manifesting in quantifiable biceps-muscle weakness that is progressing to involve the lower extremities. He therefore requires neuroimaging and probable surgical intervention rather than conservative management with physical therapy.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of gait imbalance and urinary urgency. He has a history of degenerative cervical myelopathy and underwent anterior cervical decompression 5 years ago. He denies significant neck pain. On examination, he has mild bilateral leg weakness, hyperreflexia, and a wide-based gait, while light touch sensation is largely intact.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient presents with gait imbalance, mild bilateral leg weakness, hyperreflexia, and urinary urgency, indicating cervical spinal cord involvement. His history of degenerative cervical myelopathy and prior anterior cervical decompression suggests recurrence due to progressive spondylotic changes or other degenerative mechanisms causing renewed cord compression. Hyperreflexia indicates upper motor neuron involvement, while urinary urgency suggests descending autonomic pathway compromise. The preservation of light touch sensation implies relative sparing of the dorsal columns. These factors point to recurrent cervical cord compression.

Key learning point: In patients with a history of cervical myelopathy and surgical intervention, recurrent degenerative cervical myelopathy should be considered if symptoms such as gait instability and urinary urgency reappear.

B) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome typically presents with lower back pain, radicular symptoms, saddle anesthesia, and lower motor neuron signs such as flaccid weakness and decreased reflexes. The patient's hyperreflexia and wide-based gait suggest an upper motor neuron lesion, not consistent with cauda equina syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is associated with gait disturbance, urinary dysfunction, and cognitive impairment. The patient's mild bilateral leg weakness and hyperreflexia suggest an upper motor neuron process, unlike the subtle motor signs in normal pressure hydrocephalus. Cognitive changes are also typically prominent in normal pressure hydrocephalus.

D) INCORRECT:

Lumbar spinal stenosis often causes neurogenic claudication with leg pain or cramping relieved by lumbar flexion. The patient's hyperreflexia and mild bilateral leg weakness suggest an upper motor neuron process, unlike the lower motor neuron signs seen in lumbar spinal stenosis. The absence of radicular pain or back pain further distances this diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man presents with eight months of progressive hand weakness, difficulty with fine motor tasks, and occasional neck pain. He reports frequent hand numbness and unsteadiness while walking. Examination shows hyperreflexia in both upper and lower extremities, bilateral hand intrinsic muscle weakness, and a positive Hoffman sign (see report).
MRI of the cervical spine: Multilevel degenerative changes causing cord compression
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Degenerative cervical myelopathy manifests with symptoms such as hand weakness, fine motor difficulties, and gait instability due to chronic cervical spinal cord compression from spondylotic changes. Hyperreflexia and a positive Hoffmann sign indicate upper motor neuron involvement. MRI findings of multilevel degenerative changes confirm the diagnosis. Surgical evaluation is crucial as decompressive procedures, like laminectomy or anterior cervical discectomy and fusion, can halt progression and potentially improve neurological deficits by relieving spinal cord pressure.

Key learning point: In patients with degenerative cervical myelopathy and ongoing or worsening neurological symptoms, referral to spinal surgery is crucial to prevent further neurological deterioration.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy can improve mobility and strengthen muscles in musculoskeletal conditions. However, in this patient, progressive neurological deficits and MRI evidence of cord compression indicate a mechanical issue. Physical therapy does not address the compressive lesion causing the deficits, limiting its effectiveness as initial management.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral muscle relaxants alleviate discomfort from muscle spasms, such as in acute neck strain. This patient has upper motor neuron signs and MRI evidence of spinal cord compression, indicating a structural issue. Muscle relaxants do not address the mechanical compression causing myelopathic symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous corticosteroids are used for acute spinal cord injuries to reduce inflammation. This patient's condition involves chronic cervical spondylotic myelopathy due to degenerative changes, driven by mechanical stress rather than acute inflammation, making corticosteroids ineffective.
